Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1639433 - Paluch

This grant is to provide partial support for the Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (MTSM) Conference to be held on the campus of Miami University (Ohio) on May 25-27, 2016. The MTSM Conference has historically provided a forum for researchers working on theoretical and experimental aspects of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics to come together, present their work and exchange ideas. Most participants will be from chemical engineering and chemistry departments, although students and faculty from physics, materials science, mechanical engineering, and computer science departments have also participated in this conference in the past.

Intellectual Merit:
Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics are an important area of research that has a wide spectrum of applications in chemical, biological and natural systems. The MTSM Conference series has a 28-year history and attracts participants from academic institutions, industry and national laboratories. Most attendees are from institutions located in the midwest region of the US, which has a large concentration of researchers working in the field of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics. The Conference participants will have the opportunity to attend state-of-the-art invited presentations by leading experts in the field and debate controversial points with their peers.

Broader Impacts:
The conference participants supported by this grant will have the opportunity to network with peers from other institutions and exchange ideas about the current status and future directions in research and education in an important area of research: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics. A distinctive feature of The MTSM Conference is its focus on researchers in the early stages of their academic careers, such as undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty. Because the meetings are regional and organization costs are kept to a minimum, faculty members are often able to travel with their entire group to the meeting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project enabled the 2016 Midwest Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (MTSM) Conference, which was hosted on the campus of Miami University, Oxford, Ohio for the first time, from May 25-27, 2016. This annual conference provides a regional scientific presentation and exchange venue for undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, young and senior faculty, and also participants from industry and national laboratories. For many students, this is their first presentation at a major technical meeting and thereby benefit from this formative experience.


Specific objectives were to: (1) provide a smaller-scale scientific venue facilitating detailed research exchanges without the distraction of parallel sessions, (2) facilitate professional and career mentoring, networking and scientific exchange for undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs and young faculty in a conducive, informal atmosphere, and (3) promote the MTSM Conference going into the future.


The conference was organized around five sessions (one poster and four oral): (1) Posters, 7 posters, (2) Macromolecules and Colloids, 7 talks, (3) Phase Equilibria, 12 talks, (4) Adsorption and Interfaces, 7 talks, (5) Biomolecular Systems, 6 talks. There were four invited, plenary lectures highlighting the advances made by rising assistant professors, and started each session of oral talks: Jonathan Whitmer, University of Notre Dame, spoke on Designing Soft Materials with Free Energy Mapping; Neeraj Rai, Mississippi State University, spoke on Modeling Vapor Liquid Phase Equilibria: Past, Present, and Future; Christopher Wilmer, University of Pittsburgh, spoke on Mechanics of Heat Transfer in Porous Crystals Containing Adsorbed Gases; Sumit Sharma, Ohio University, spoke on Water in Biological Systems: Evaporation Transition and Hydrophobic Collapse. The conference was also an opportunity to help prepare Drs. Whitmer and Wilmer for organization of MTSM in 2017 and 2018, respectively.


Student and postdoc participants also benefitted from a keynote address by Dr. Alan M. Ferrenberg, Associate Vice President, Solution Delivery and Deputy CIO, Information Technology Services, Miami University. Dr. Ferrenberg performed pioneering research in the field of molecular simulation as a student and postdoc. His talk described his career trajectory, offering encouragement and advice.
